course.subject: IEDA
course.name: E-Commerce Technology and Applications
course.description: A significant portion of modern commercial activity is dependent on electronic commerce. In this course, students will gain familiarity with common e-commerce business models and get an understanding of how and when they are used. The course will cover important enabling technologies, including basics of internet communication, security, clouds, as well as low level technology enabling functions such as localization and tracking. Several important applications in various sectors of industry, including visualization and analysis as well as ELogistics will be introduced.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q (prior to 2020-21)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Words failed me on describing his teaching. Ajay has joined HKUST 20 years and he could single-handly ace all the other professors here in HKUST in terms of teaching methodologies (including Desmond form CS). He could reduce every topics, from Lasso regression to PCA analysis to even RSA encryptions every single one of them, to basic algebra or even something simpler: "PCA is just looking at these pens in this direction- oh they clumped together, that's not good :/, so we rotate-ate-ate- oh here! they are all spread now!" BOOM!, that's the idea. I was like OMG that's it?! It is so much simpler than the COMP4331 I am taking! All advanced concepts, reduced to atom. That is how amazing/wonderful/excellent/(whatever positive adjective) his teaching is.

Tutorials: Average Chinese mainland PGs, you know what I mean.

reviews.author: wei√übrot
reviews.title: Interesting course, introduces basics and provides good practice
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers some important enabling technologies such as the basics of internet communication and security in addition to three application types: search, demand forecasting, and customer acquisition. We wrote short python programs for each subsection and covered techniques such as graph search, data processing and visualization via dimension reduction, regression, clustering and classification.
The topics will be covered in the following sequence:
1. Foundations: Infrastructure and protocols of the web, sessions, security basics
2. Search: web as a graph, graph search basics, crawling basics
3. Visualization: simple interactive graphical informatics
4. Demand forecasting: Simple regression models, Bass diffusion model
5. Customer acquisition: Clustering, classification; [time permitting: Discrete choice models]
reviews.comment_teaching: AJ is very approachable and keeps the lectures interesting. He does his best to involve students in the class and asks us for feedback. The TA was also very helpful and both were always quick to respond to any question.

reviews.comment_workload: If you have experience with python, the projects and hw should be easily doable. The concepts are explained well and a lot of examples are given. It's more about applying the concepts from class and learning to use libraries than about programming itself. But even if you don't know python the basics will be introduced and the TA and professor are always there to help.
